quotes.topic_title: Cold open: Zigging versus startup conventional wisdom
quotes.text: Some of the best startup advice I've heard is startups should focus on one thing and be really, really exceptionally world-class at that one thing.
quotes.speaker: Dharmesh Shah
quotes.context: Highlights a common piece of startup conventional wisdom that teams can use as a baseline when deciding whether to specialize or diversify early.

quotes.topic_title: Cold open: Zigging versus startup conventional wisdom
quotes.text: And one of our early zigs is we are going to do exactly the opposite of that.
quotes.speaker: Dharmesh Shah
quotes.context: A counterintuitive example of deliberately rejecting standard advice, reinforcing the idea that strategic differentiation can come from doing the opposite of the norm.

quotes.topic_title: Rapid-fire fun facts about Dharmesh
quotes.text: That is correct. 7,000 plus employees? Exactly zero direct reports from time, T equals zero.
quotes.speaker: Dharmesh Shah
quotes.context: A contrarian leadership model: operating at massive scale without direct reports challenges conventional org design assumptions.

quotes.topic_title: Rapid-fire fun facts about Dharmesh
quotes.text: You built many side projects while at HubSpot, including a product called Wordplay, which at one point made $90,000 per month and had 16 million users.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A concrete example of side projects reaching significant revenue and user scale, suggesting a path for experimentation alongside a core role.

quotes.topic_title: Rapid-fire fun facts about Dharmesh
quotes.text: I try to not do things that I'm not good at and don't enjoy. One of the rare exceptions that has snuck through is the need for me to get on stages as founder when we have our annual HubSpot event, our conference, which at the time when we did our first one, it was, like, 150 people at the Marriott. And then it's steadily grown since then, and so now it'll be like, 10,000 people in the live audience and hundreds of thousands online.
quotes.speaker: Dharmesh Shah
quotes.context: A practical decision rule (avoid tasks you’re bad at/don’t enjoy) plus an explicit exception for high-leverage founder responsibilities like public speaking.

quotes.topic_title: Keynote craft: engineering humor with LPM
quotes.text: I'm a big believer in this talent versus skill. So we all understand talent. It's like if someone has a talent for music, someone has a talent for athletics, whatever it happens to be. And that's true. That exists, but the way I think about it is talent basically controls the slope of the curve, but most things are actually acquirable skills.
quotes.speaker: Dharmesh Shah
quotes.context: A practical mental model for learning: talent affects learning speed, but skill acquisition is available to most people with the right approach.

quotes.topic_title: Keynote craft: engineering humor with LPM
quotes.text: And lesson number two is that there is a process, and this is the engineer in me of just kind of functional decomposition of a problem to say, " Okay, in order for me to be a pretty good public speaker, what are the underlying sub-skills required in order to accomplish that? Okay, skill number one, you have to be able to stand up on stage and not pass out."
quotes.speaker: Dharmesh Shah
quotes.context: Shows a repeatable methodology—break a complex performance skill into trainable sub-skills starting from the minimum viable capability.

quotes.topic_title: Keynote craft: engineering humor with LPM
quotes.text: I have custom software that I've written that will say, "Okay, here are the points at which the audience laughed." Actually audibly laughed. That's the only way it counts. And this actually... and it comes down to this metric that standup comedians use called LPM laughs per minute.
quotes.speaker: Dharmesh Shah
quotes.context: Introduces a measurable KPI (LPM) for keynote humor, turning a subjective goal into an instrumented feedback loop.

quotes.topic_title: Keynote craft: engineering humor with LPM
quotes.text: It's like, okay, if you're solving literally for that ratio of laughs per minute, there are two ways to improve it. One is to add more laughs. Two is to decrease the number of words between laughs, right?
quotes.speaker: Dharmesh Shah
quotes.context: A simple optimization framework practitioners can apply immediately when revising talks: increase laugh frequency or tighten pacing between laughs.

quotes.topic_title: Keynote craft: engineering humor with LPM
quotes.text: Anyway. And that's a long way of saying if I can get up on a public stage and learn that particular skill, anyone can learn just about anything. It just comes down to practice and measurement and just getting incrementally better over time.
quotes.speaker: Dharmesh Shah
quotes.context: A contrarian, empowering takeaway: systematic practice plus measurement beats “natural ability” for high-stakes speaking.

quotes.topic_title: Tactical tips for being funnier on stage
quotes.text: So once you deliver it, then you have to stop talking.
quotes.speaker: Dharmesh Shah
quotes.context: A tactical delivery rule: end on the punchline and pause so the audience has space to react and laugh.

quotes.topic_title: Tactical tips for being funnier on stage
quotes.text: And the reason you have to stop talking is the audience needs about a half a second to react, and then they want the permission to laugh.
quotes.speaker: Dharmesh Shah
quotes.context: A simple mental model for timing: laughter requires a brief processing beat plus a clear signal you’re done.

quotes.topic_title: Tactical tips for being funnier on stage
quotes.text: So leverage the investment you've already made in establishing context and scene, and then just squeeze more humor into the end of it in punctuated fashion.
quotes.speaker: Dharmesh Shah
quotes.context: A reusable structure for business storytelling: amortize setup costs by stacking multiple punchlines within one story.

quotes.topic_title: Tactical tips for being funnier on stage
quotes.text: In business talks, you actually have another agenda other than just being entertaining. You actually have a message. You're trying to promote something. Promote an idea, promote a product.
quotes.speaker: Dharmesh Shah
quotes.context: A counterpoint to stand-up: business speakers should optimize humor within the constraints of delivering a message.

quotes.topic_title: Tactical tips for being funnier on stage
quotes.text: So anyway, in my mind, for most normal circumstance, even if you can get above a one, 1.2, 25, you're in the top decile in terms of top, generally given by non-professionals.
quotes.speaker: Dharmesh Shah
quotes.context: A concrete benchmark for laughs-per-minute (LPM) that sets realistic targets for non-professional speakers.

quotes.topic_title: SoloWare: building tools for one user
quotes.text: I have this notion of what I call SoloWare.
quotes.speaker: Dharmesh Shah
quotes.context: Introduces a named framework for building software primarily for a single user (yourself) before considering broader distribution.

quotes.topic_title: SoloWare: building tools for one user
quotes.text: And SoloWare is exactly what it sounds like. It's software built for exactly one person, and in my case, that one person is me.
quotes.speaker: Dharmesh Shah
quotes.context: Defines the SoloWare concept in a crisp, memorable way that practitioners can use to guide what they build and why.

quotes.topic_title: SoloWare: building tools for one user
quotes.text: And the most important thing is that because it's only for one person, if it stops bringing utility, you can just turn it off. You can just stop using it.
quotes.speaker: Dharmesh Shah
quotes.context: Highlights the key operational advantage of SoloWare: you can discontinue instantly when ROI drops, without external obligations.

quotes.topic_title: SoloWare: building tools for one user
quotes.text: Versus if you have users, even 10 users, and you put it out there and then people would be disappointed if you took it down for whatever reason, that's kind of hard.
quotes.speaker: Dharmesh Shah
quotes.context: A counterintuitive reminder that even a tiny user base creates real product and support commitments that are costly to unwind.

quotes.topic_title: SoloWare: building tools for one user
quotes.text: So anyway, that's the calculus I go through, "Is this useful enough to enough people where it's worth the calories of making it non-solo ware, making it even micro-ware?"
quotes.speaker: Dharmesh Shah
quotes.context: Offers a practical decision test for when to productize an internal tool: weigh broad utility against the ongoing cost of supporting users.

quotes.topic_title: Why Dharmesh has zero direct reports
quotes.text: I don't want to spend any years of my life becoming passively okay at something.
quotes.speaker: Dharmesh Shah
quotes.context: A clear prioritization rule: don’t invest time to become mediocre at a weakness—double down on strengths instead.

quotes.topic_title: Why Dharmesh has zero direct reports
quotes.text: I would rather take those same calories and take the things that I'm good at that I actually enjoy.
quotes.speaker: Dharmesh Shah
quotes.context: A practical resource-allocation mindset (“calories”) for choosing work that compounds both performance and motivation.

quotes.topic_title: Why Dharmesh has zero direct reports
quotes.text: You tend to be good at the things you enjoy. You tend to enjoy the things you're good at.
quotes.speaker: Dharmesh Shah
quotes.context: A simple heuristic for identifying high-leverage work: look for the overlap between enjoyment and competence.

quotes.topic_title: Why Dharmesh has zero direct reports
quotes.text: right now I can honestly say I'm having a better time at HubSpot now at 7,000 people than I was having at 70 people.
quotes.speaker: Dharmesh Shah
quotes.context: A counterintuitive example that scale can increase personal satisfaction if you design your role to avoid the parts you’re bad at.

quotes.topic_title: Why Dharmesh has zero direct reports
quotes.text: I get all the upside of scale, which is I can make big bets. So we can have long-term things and plans, whatever, and plan for global domination without the downsides of scale, which is, "Oh, you're having to manage all these people and all the kind of mechanics."
quotes.speaker: Dharmesh Shah
quotes.context: A role-design model: structure your job to capture scale’s leverage (big bets) while minimizing scale’s operational burdens (people mechanics).

quotes.topic_title: Designing company rules: no meetings before 11
quotes.text: Yeah, it's amazing what you can get away with in terms of shaping the universe to your liking.
quotes.speaker: Dharmesh Shah
quotes.context: A mindset shift for founders: many “defaults” are optional, and you can intentionally design norms instead of inheriting them.

quotes.topic_title: Designing company rules: no meetings before 11
quotes.text: I think people automatically assume that things have to go a certain way, especially founders and first time founders.
quotes.speaker: Dharmesh Shah
quotes.context: Highlights a common trap—treating conventional company practices as fixed—which blocks experimentation with better operating rules.

quotes.topic_title: Designing company rules: no meetings before 11
quotes.text: And so we made it just from the early days of HubSpot in the early years at least, we're like, "No meetings before 11 A.M. Period."
quotes.speaker: Dharmesh Shah
quotes.context: A concrete, replicable policy example for protecting maker time and aligning company rhythms to how the team actually works.

quotes.topic_title: Designing company rules: no meetings before 11
quotes.text: And then we adjusted it, I think maybe three or four years and we're like, "All right, we could have meetings before 11:00 AM. You just can't invite one of the co-founders to it. So you're welcome to meet amongst yourselves if you choose to do so."
quotes.speaker: Dharmesh Shah
quotes.context: Shows an iterative approach to company rules: relax constraints while preserving the original intent via a targeted exception.

quotes.topic_title: Designing company rules: no meetings before 11
quotes.text: I have a personal rule where I have no meetings before 3:00 P.M. because I don't work anywhere. I can more so create my schedule, but the idea is I create this deep work time in the beginnings of the day.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: An actionable scheduling tactic—front-load deep work by pushing meetings later—to improve focus and output.

quotes.topic_title: Going public: benefits founders underestimate
quotes.text: I think too many founders, once they get to a... They are very apprehensive of going public and going through the IPO process and being a publicly traded company because they think... I mean, that's like the beginning of the end. "It's going to change everything and my life is going to suck."
quotes.speaker: Dharmesh Shah
quotes.context: Contrarian reframing that founders often overestimate the downsides of going public.

quotes.topic_title: Going public: benefits founders underestimate
quotes.text: One of the nicest things, and this is underappreciated, is that we know right now what the market values HubSpot at. I can tell you that any business day of the week.
quotes.speaker: Dharmesh Shah
quotes.context: Highlights a practical benefit of being public: continuous, transparent price discovery versus episodic private valuations.

quotes.topic_title: Going public: benefits founders underestimate
quotes.text: So, if you focus on creating values, here's what we're actually building, valuation will sometimes be higher than you deserve, sometimes will be lower than you deserve, but over the fullness of time, those two things will move in lockstep, right?
quotes.speaker: Dharmesh Shah
quotes.context: A mental model for staying long-term focused: build intrinsic value and let market valuation converge over time.

quotes.topic_title: Going public: benefits founders underestimate
quotes.text: In the subsequent years, we went from a billion dollars in market cap to 30 billion, which is roughly what it is now. That first billion of market cap creation, a very small number of people got to participate in. The rest of the $29 billion in market cap, everyone, every public investor got a chance to participate in.
quotes.speaker: Dharmesh Shah
quotes.context: Concrete example showing how IPOs broaden wealth participation beyond early private investors.

quotes.topic_title: Radical transparency: everyone becomes an insider
quotes.text: just because you're a public company does not mandate that you do certain things.
quotes.speaker: Dharmesh Shah
quotes.context: Reframes going public as not requiring founders to abandon their operating philosophy beyond baseline disclosure requirements.

quotes.topic_title: Radical transparency: everyone becomes an insider
quotes.text: if you don't agree with this approach, you should not buy Amazon shares. It's like, it's a completely optional thing. "You don't have to buy it, but this is the way we're going to run the business."
quotes.speaker: Dharmesh Shah
quotes.context: A clear mental model for setting expectations with investors: make the strategy explicit and let the market self-select.

quotes.topic_title: Radical transparency: everyone becomes an insider
quotes.text: all information within HubSpot is equally shared with everyone in the company, period.
quotes.speaker: Dharmesh Shah
quotes.context: A simple, enforceable rule for operationalizing radical transparency as a default rather than a selective practice.

quotes.topic_title: Radical transparency: everyone becomes an insider
quotes.text: we discovered through that mathematical induction process, is like, "If it's true for N, is it true for N plus one?" Is that there's no actual legal limit to how many insiders a company can have.
quotes.speaker: Dharmesh Shah
quotes.context: A novel problem-solving approach: pressure-test assumed constraints step-by-step until you find the real boundary.

quotes.topic_title: Radical transparency: everyone becomes an insider
quotes.text: we designated every single employee to be a designated insider.
quotes.speaker: Dharmesh Shah
quotes.context: A concrete, counterintuitive mechanism HubSpot used post-IPO to preserve open financial sharing at scale.

quotes.topic_title: Contrarian bets and iterating: SMB focus and titles
quotes.text: So what I think of is high conviction, low consensus bets.
quotes.speaker: Dharmesh Shah
quotes.context: A simple decision-making framework for choosing contrarian strategies that can create durable advantage.

quotes.topic_title: Contrarian bets and iterating: SMB focus and titles
quotes.text: So the number of things that you're a contrarian on has to be greater than zero, but not too high.
quotes.speaker: Dharmesh Shah
quotes.context: Practical guidance on limiting contrarianism to a few key dimensions so the organization stays coherent and executable.

quotes.topic_title: Contrarian bets and iterating: SMB focus and titles
quotes.text: You need to be right about something that other people think you're wrong about for a very long time.
quotes.speaker: Dharmesh Shah
quotes.context: A memorable articulation of the endurance required for low-consensus bets to pay off.

quotes.topic_title: Contrarian bets and iterating: SMB focus and titles
quotes.text: No, you don't understand. This is not a go-to market strategy. This is not like, "Oh, we're going to conquer SMB first," this is not Bowling Pin, this is not Geoffrey Moore, this is a, "We are here for SMB." That's what we're doing.
quotes.speaker: Dharmesh Shah
quotes.context: A concrete example of committing to a target market as an identity-level choice rather than a sequencing tactic.

quotes.topic_title: Contrarian bets and iterating: SMB focus and titles
quotes.text: And by virtue of you not giving us titles, that means you're having to compensate us in an economic sense in other ways.
quotes.speaker: Dharmesh Shah
quotes.context: A counterintuitive compensation/retention insight: non-monetary status signals can substitute for cash and affect total rewards strategy.

quotes.topic_title: Simplicity as a system: pay, access, seating lottery
quotes.text: One of the things that I think are applicable is just this need to solve for simplicity. It's like the simpler you can make things in the early years, the better off you generally are.
quotes.speaker: Dharmesh Shah
quotes.context: A generalizable operating principle for startups: prioritize simplicity early to reduce overhead and decision fatigue.

quotes.topic_title: Simplicity as a system: pay, access, seating lottery
quotes.text: Okay, well, A, binary decisions are much easier than non-binary decisions. It's like, "Okay, everything or nothing is much, much simpler."
quotes.speaker: Dharmesh Shah
quotes.context: A mental model for policy design: default to binary rules to avoid endless edge-case debates and complexity.

quotes.topic_title: Simplicity as a system: pay, access, seating lottery
quotes.text: And we just kept doing it because it's like, "Okay, well, until it breaks, we'll just keep doing that."
quotes.speaker: Dharmesh Shah
quotes.context: An iterative scaling heuristic: keep a simple rule in place until reality forces you to add complexity.

quotes.topic_title: Simplicity as a system: pay, access, seating lottery
quotes.text: And so what we did is we said, "Oh, we'll just do a lottery."
quotes.speaker: Dharmesh Shah
quotes.context: A concrete mechanism for fairness and simplicity that removes subjective decision-making (and the politics that come with it).

quotes.topic_title: Simplicity as a system: pay, access, seating lottery
quotes.text: So the moral of the story is, that one decision of simplifying, can you imagine the amount of politics we avoided?
quotes.speaker: Dharmesh Shah
quotes.context: A contrarian claim that simple systems can eliminate large amounts of organizational friction and wasted energy.

quotes.topic_title: Fighting entropy: simplicity versus complexity at scale
quotes.text: Okay, so in lay person's terms, the second law of thermodynamics, I'm paraphrasing here, is that, "Over time, unless you intervene, everything goes to crap." I'm paraphrasing.
quotes.speaker: Dharmesh Shah
quotes.context: A memorable mental model that frames leadership as requiring active intervention to prevent organizational decay.

quotes.topic_title: Fighting entropy: simplicity versus complexity at scale
quotes.text: But then the third stage is you're fighting complexity.
quotes.speaker: Dharmesh Shah
quotes.context: A simple stage-based framework for what becomes the dominant challenge as companies scale.

quotes.topic_title: Fighting entropy: simplicity versus complexity at scale
quotes.text: Complexity does kill companies. Maybe not as quickly as other things, but much more reliably than other things.
quotes.speaker: Dharmesh Shah
quotes.context: A counterintuitive warning that complexity is a slow but highly dependable failure mode practitioners should prioritize against.

quotes.topic_title: Fighting entropy: simplicity versus complexity at scale
quotes.text: And so this is why it's never too early to plant the seeds of simplicity, put them in there, make that part of the culture of the organization.
quotes.speaker: Dharmesh Shah
quotes.context: Actionable advice to institutionalize simplicity early, before scale makes complexity harder to unwind.

quotes.topic_title: Fighting entropy: simplicity versus complexity at scale
quotes.text: And the message we're trying to convey is, "Simplicity is worth fighting for." That's thing number one, it's important, but the other one is that it requires fighting for. It does not happen, and it will be a fight, because the universe is working against you.
quotes.speaker: Dharmesh Shah
quotes.context: A culture-level operating principle that emphasizes simplicity as an ongoing, resourced effort rather than a default outcome.

quotes.topic_title: Product simplicity: feature tradeoffs and complexity costs
quotes.text: we had a rule in the HubSpot product as the product grew in those early years that every time you added what we thought of as a knob or dial, called a feature, you had to take one out somewhere else.
quotes.speaker: Dharmesh Shah
quotes.context: A simple, enforceable product rule that forces teams to make explicit tradeoffs and cap UI/feature complexity as the product grows.

quotes.topic_title: Product simplicity: feature tradeoffs and complexity costs
quotes.text: The other mistake I think people make in product all the time is that we measure the cost of a feature based on the, usually, or even a new product, based on the cost of implementation.
quotes.speaker: Dharmesh Shah
quotes.context: A warning that feature decisions are often made with an incomplete cost model that overweights build effort and underweights downstream costs.

quotes.topic_title: Product simplicity: feature tradeoffs and complexity costs
quotes.text: The third-order thinking, which I think is the most nuanced, and it turns out to be the most important, is the other costs that complexity adds.
quotes.speaker: Dharmesh Shah
quotes.context: A mental model for evaluating features/products beyond build and maintenance—focusing on the compounding organizational costs of complexity.

quotes.topic_title: Product simplicity: feature tradeoffs and complexity costs
quotes.text: No, what actually happens is that now when you go from product one to two, you have added dimensional complexity to your business.
quotes.speaker: Dharmesh Shah
quotes.context: A counterintuitive framing that adding a product isn’t linear growth in complexity; it changes the dimensionality of decision-making across the company.

quotes.topic_title: Product simplicity: feature tradeoffs and complexity costs
quotes.text: now every decision you make has to be made through the lens of, "Now we have two products. We just hired an engineer, do they work on product number one or product number two? We're going to launch a marketing campaign. Do we spend five minutes talking about product number one and two minutes talking about product number two? How do we do anything?"
quotes.speaker: Dharmesh Shah
quotes.context: Concrete examples of how multi-product complexity multiplies coordination and prioritization decisions across hiring, marketing, and execution.
